scenario:
PayPal's stock price surged during the pandemic years, reaching an all-time high of $309 per share in July 2025, but has since declined to around $67. The company's growth metrics have slowed down, with total payment volume growth decreasing from 50% in Q1 2021 to 7% in Q4 2024, and adjusted EPS growth from 85% to 5%. However, the new management team, led by former Intuit executive Alex Chriss, has implemented several initiatives to restore growth, including the creation of an advertising platform and a cash-back debit card product.

PayPal's future growth strategies include monetizing Venmo, capturing a significant share of the offline payment market, and consolidating its platform to focus on building its ecosystem. The company aims to achieve $2 billion in Venmo revenue by 2027 and has an ambitious vision to get the earnings growth rate above 20% over the long run.

PayPal trades at a relatively low valuation of 13.3 times forward earnings estimates and 11 times forward free cash flow, with a net cash position on its balance sheet. The company is expected to generate around $6 billion in free cash flow in 2025, with management planning to use substantially all of it to buy back shares. If management can achieve its growth targets, the stock could be considered an incredible bargain at the current price.
